questions.text: As medical director of a health maintenance organization, you are asked to update screening recommendations for enrolled members. You find that recommendations are lacking in the field of sexually transmitted diseases. You decide to develop evidence-based screening guidelines for Chlamydia trachomatis. Which of the following criteria is the most important for developing routine screening recommendations?

options.label: A
options.text: Number of sexual partners

options.label: B
options.text: Use barrier methods such as condoms

options.label: C
options.text: Age

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of symptoms

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Age Women are particularly at risk of developing complications from the disease and should be the first group to be targeted for screening. Age has consistently been shown to be a risk factor for disease, regardless of the other behaviors described. Women under 20 should be screened at any pelvic examination at least once a year.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option : A & B. Sexually active women between the ages of 20 and 24 should be screened yearly, regardless of the presence or absence of risky behaviors. Since most chlamydial infections are asymptomatic in both men and women, most transmissions occur among persons who are unknowingly infected. Option : D. When symptoms are present, the test is diagnostic. Screening, by definition, is detecting a condition before symptoms occur.

questions.text: A 35-week pregnant woman comes to an antenatal clinic at a nearby PHC. She has said that she doesn’t have any antenatal check-ups till now. In this case, the best approach regarding tetanus immunization would be to:

options.label: A
options.text: Do not waste the TT vaccine as it would be of no use in this pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: Give a dose of Tetanus Toxoid (TT) and explain to her that it will not protect the newborn and she should take the second dose after four weeks even if she delivers.

options.label: C
options.text: Give one dose of TT and explain that it will not be helpful for this pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: Give her anti-Tetanus Immunoglobulin and the TT vaccine

questions.correct_answer: B. Give a dose of Tetanus Toxoid (TT) and explain to her that it will not protect the newborn and she should take the second dose after four weeks even if she delivers.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Give a dose of Tetanus Toxoid (TT) and explain to her that it will not protect the newborn and she should take the second dose after four weeks even if she delivers. TETANUS: If the mother was not immunized earlier, two doses of adsorbed tetanus toxoid should be given - the first at 16- 20 weeks and the second at 20-24 weeks of pregnancy. The minimum interval between the two doses should be one month. No pregnant woman should be denied even one dose of tetanus toxoid if she is seen late in pregnancy. One booster dose will be sufficient for a woman who has been immunized earlier. When such a booster has been given, it will provide the necessary cover for subsequent pregnancies during the next five It is advised not to inject tetanus toxoid at every successive pregnancy because of the risk of hyperimmunization and side effects.

questions.text: In a given country A, the total number of births in the year 2020 is 6150. From these Births, 50 neonates die within the first ten days of life, whereas the number of deaths within 10-28 days of life is 250. Still Birth in the year 2020 is 150. What is the Neonatal mortality rate in Country A?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

50 Total Births = 6150 But, Still Birth in the year 2020 = 150 So, Total Live Birth in 2020 = 6150 – 150 = 6000 Neonates Died Within ten days of life = 50 Number of deaths within 10-28 days of life = 250 Therefore, Total Deaths within 28 days of life = 300 So, Neonatal Mortality Rate = (300 x 1000) / 6000 = 50

questions.text: In a population of 5000, with a birth rate of 30/1000 Population, 15 children died during the first year of life in one year: of these 9 died during the first month of life. What is the infant mortality rate in this population?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

100 So Population = 5000 , Birth Rate = 30/1000 Therefore Total Birth = 150 Children died Less than 1 yr of age = 15 So IMR = (15/150) x 1000 = 100

questions.text: A 10-month-old child is presented in the primary health centre with a history of cough and cold for the last six days with unable to drink for the last 12 hours. On examination, he has a respiratory rate of 48 breaths per minute. There is an absence of chest indrawing the weight of the baby is 5 kg. On further investigation, he was a term baby with a normal vaginal delivery and no significant disease history after birth. Also, no significant family history was present. The child must be suffering from

options.label: A
options.text: Severe pneumonia

options.label: B
options.text: Pneumonia

options.label: C
options.text: Very severe pneumonia

options.label: D
options.text: No pneumonia

questions.explanation:
Solution:

No pneumonia In the question the child is 10 months and has a respiratory rate of 48 per minute, which is normal but there is an absence of chest indrawing, which is a feature of severe pneumonia but also, the child has a weight 5kg is the expected weight at 10 month age is 92 9.5 kgs so the child is a severe malnutrition according to Gomez classification hence it is a case of very severe pneumonia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. In severe pneumonia, there is not severe malnutrition Option: B. Presence of chest indrawing indicates it is not only pneumonia Option: C. No fast breathing present in plain cold and cough (no pneumonia) SIGNS CLASSIFY AS IDENTIFY TREATMENT (Urgent pre-referral treatments are in bold print) ● Any general danger sign or ● Chest indrawing or ● Stridor in calm child SEVERE PNEUMONIA OR VERY SEVERE DISEASE ● Give first dose of Cotrimoxazole ● Refer URGENTLY to hospital ● Fast breathing PNEUMONIA ● Give Cotrimoxazole for 5 days. ● Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy. ● Advise mother when to return immediately. ● Follow-up in 2 days. ● No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease. NO PNEUMONIA: COUGH OR COLD ● If coughing for more than 21 days, refer for assessment. ● Soothe the throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy ● Advise mother when to return immediately ● Follow-up in 5 days if not improving.

questions.text: The most common indirect cause of maternal mortality in our country is:

options.label: A
options.text: Hemorrhage

options.label: B
options.text: Anemia

options.label: C
options.text: Heart disease

options.label: D
options.text: Infection

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anemia The determinants of maternal mortality in INDIA ARE: MEDICAL CAUSES: toxemia of pregnancy, hemorrhage, infection, obstructed labour, unsafe abortion Non-Obstetric causes: anemia (M/C), associated diseases( cardiac, renal, hepatic or metabolic and infectious), malignancy, accidents Social factors: age at childbirth, parity, malnutrition, poverty, illiteracy, lack of maternal services, social customs etc. Hemorrhage is the most common direct cause of maternal mortality in india

questions.text: According to the School health services, All of the following are minimum standards for sanitation of schools and its environment in India except:

options.label: A
options.text: Combined doors + windows area = 25 % of floor space area

options.label: B
options.text: One urinal for 10 students and one latrine for 25 Students

options.label: C
options.text: Classroom should have sufficient natural light preferably from the left

options.label: D
options.text: There should be one urinal for 60 students and one latrine for 100 student

questions.correct_answer: B. One urinal for 10 students and one latrine for 25 Students
questions.explanation:
Solution:

One urinal for 10 students and one latrine for 25 Students Healthful school environment: Suggested minimum standards for sanitation of schools and its environs in India include, Location: Away from noisy surroundings; kept fenced Site: 5 acres for primary schools; 10 acres for higher elementary schools Structure: Exterior walls 10 inches thick and heat resistant Classroom : 1 classroom per 40 students maximum; Per capita space > 10 sq. feet Furniture: Single desks of ‘minus (–) type’ Doors and windows: Doors and windows area > 25% of floor area Color: Inside color of walls should be white Lighting: Natural light from left side Water supply: Safe and potable and continuous supply through taps Lavatory: 1 urinal per 60 students and 1 latrine per 100 students

questions.text: In the given Image, a yellow colored zone is between which two curves:

options.label: A
options.text: Just Below the 50th percentile for boys

options.label: B
options.text: Between the 3rd percentile for girls and 3SD below of reference

options.label: C
options.text: Between Reference Standard and 2SD below of reference standard

options.label: D
options.text: Between 3rd percentile for girls and 2SD below of reference

questions.correct_answer: B. Between the 3rd percentile for girls and 3SD below of reference
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Between the 3rd percentile for girls and 3SD below of reference The given Image is ICDS Growth Chart. ICDS Growth chart has 3 reference curves: Reference standard ( 50th percentile for boys) 2SD below of reference standard ( 3rd percentile for girls) 3SD below reference standard So yellow coloured zone (Underweight Zone) is between 2SD below of reference standard (3rd percentile for girls) and 3SD below reference standard.

questions.text: The guidelines according to the given Image Initiative include all except

options.label: A
options.text: Mothers to initiate breastfeeding within 4 hours of normal delivery

options.label: B
options.text: Mothers and infants to be together for 24 hours a day

options.label: C
options.text: Giving newborn infants no food or drink other than breast milk

options.label: D
options.text: Encouraging breastfeeding on demand

questions.correct_answer: A. Mothers to initiate breastfeeding within 4 hours of normal delivery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mothers to initiate breastfeeding within 4 hours of normal delivery BFHI is Supported by the major professional medical and nursing Bodies in India. The global BFHI has listed ten steps that the hospital must fulfill. This includes: Have a written Breastfeeding policy that is routinely communicated to all Health care st,:1ff: Train all health care staff in skills necessary to implement this policy; Inform all pregnant women about the benefits and management of breastfeeding; Help mothers initiate breastfeeding within one half-hour of birth; Show mother how to breastfeed and Maintain lactation. Even if they should be separated from Their infants; Give newborn infants no food or drink Other than breast milk, not even sips of water. Unless Medically indicated; Practice rooming-in – that is, allow Mothers and infants to remain together 24 hours a day; Encourage breastfeeding on demand; Provide no artificial teats or pacifiers (dummies or soothers) to breastfeeding infants, and (10) Foster the establishment of breastfeeding support groups and refer mothers to them on discharge from the hospital or clinic.

questions.text: In Country A, with a Total Population of 100000, the Live Birth of this country is 5000, with an Infant Mortality Rate of 55. No. of children who died between 1-5 years of age are 225. What is the Child Survival Index of this Country A?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

90 So, Live Birth = 5000 Since, IMR = 55 then No of infants died = (55x5000)/1000 = 275 Given No of Children died between 1-5 yr age = 225 Total no. Of child death Under 5 yr of age = 275+225 = 500 Under 5 Mortality Rate = (500 x 1000) / 5000 = 100 Therefore, Child Survival Index = (1000 – 100)/10 = 90

questions.text: A Low Birthweight baby was born in Primary Healthcare Center. He was thin and hypoxic, and his body temperature was also low. Doctors suggested the mother for providing Kangaroo Mother care to the newborn. All are the components of Kangaroo Mother care except:

options.label: A
options.text: Skin-to-skin positioning of a baby on the Mother’s chest

options.label: B
options.text: Adequate Nutrition through Breast feeding

options.label: C
options.text: Ambulatory Care as a result of earlier discharge from Hospital

options.label: D
options.text: Approach the cause of Prematurity of Baby

questions.correct_answer: D. Approach the cause of Prematurity of Baby
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Approach the cause of Prematurity of Baby Kangaroo Mother Care include: Skin-to-skin positioning of a baby on the mother's chest; Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding. Ambulatory care as a result of earlier discharge from the hospital; and Support for the mother and her family in caring for the baby

questions.text: Antenatal care is care provided to Pregnant women and Pregnant adolescent girls. Which one of the following objectives of Antenatal care is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: To promote, protect and maintain the mother's health during pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: To provide a temperature of 38 deg C or over during labour. There should be a close liaison between domiciliary and institutional delivery services

options.label: C
options.text: To detect "high-risk" cases and give them special attention

options.label: D
options.text: To sensitize the mother to the need for family planning, including advice to cases seeking medical termination of pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: B. To provide a temperature of 38 deg C or over during labour. There should be a close liaison between domiciliary and institutional delivery services
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To provide a temperature of 38 deg C or over during labour. There should be a close liaison between domiciliary and institutional delivery services The objectives of Antenatal Care are: To promote, protect and maintain the mother's health during pregnancy; To detect "high-risk" cases and give them special attention; To foresee complications and prevent them; To remove anxiety and dread associated with delivery; To reduce maternal and infant mortality and morbidity; To teach the mother elements of child care, nutrition, personal hygiene, and environmental sanitation; To sensitize the mother to the need for family planning, including advice to cases seeking medical termination of pregnancy; and To attend to the under-fives accompanying the mother.

questions.text: All are true regarding Congenital Syphilis except:

options.label: A
options.text: Infection of the fetus most commonly occurs in 1st trimester

options.label: B
options.text: Procaine Penicillin can prevent it satisfactorily

options.label: C
options.text: Neurological damage with mental retardation can be a serious consequence

options.label: D
options.text: If the mother has Late syphilis, chances of transmission decreases

questions.correct_answer: A. Infection of the fetus most commonly occurs in 1st trimester
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Infection of the fetus most commonly occurs in 1st trimester When the mother is suffering from syphilis, transmission occurs to the fetus, but not before the 4th month of pregnancy; It is most likely to occur after the 6th month when Langhans’ cell layer has completely atrophied.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. Ten daily injections of procaine penicillin (600,000 units) are almost always adequate Option: C. Neurological damage with mental retardation is one of the most serious consequences of congenital syphilis Option: D. Infection of the fetus is most likely to occur when the mother has primary or secondary stages of syphilis than late syphilis

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about congenital rubella, except

options.label: A
options.text: It is diagnosed when the infant has IgM antibodies at birth

options.label: B
options.text: It is diagnosed when IgM antibodies persist for more than 6 months

options.label: C
options.text: Most common congenital defects are deafness, cardiac malformations, and cataracts

options.label: D
options.text: Infection after 16 weeks of gestation results in major congenital defects

questions.correct_answer: D. Infection after 16 weeks of gestation results in major congenital defects
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Infection after 16 weeks of gestation results in major congenital defects Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) refers to infants born with defects secondary to intra-uterine infection or who manifest symptoms or signs of intra-uterine infection sometime after birth. Congenital infection is considered to have occurred if the infant has IgM rubella antibodies shortly after birth or if IgG antibodies persist for more than 6 months, by which time maternally derived antibodies would have disappeared. Rubella infection in a woman who becomes infected just before conception and up to the first 8-10 weeks of gestation causes multiple congenital anomalies in 90 % of infections. The defects include Ophthalmic – cataract, micro-ophthalmia, glaucoma, pigmentary retinopathy Cardiac- peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis, PDA or VSD Auditory – Sensorineural deafness Craniofacial – microcephaly.

questions.text: All are the Services provided under Integrated Child Protection Scheme (ICPS) except:

options.label: A
options.text: Emergency outreach service through ‘Child line,’ Dedicated number is 1098. It is a 24-hour toll-free Telephone service available to all children in distress

options.label: B
options.text: Open shelters for children in need in urban and semi-urban areas

options.label: C
options.text: To raise public Spending on Health to at least 2-3% of GDP

options.label: D
options.text: Web-enabled child protection management system Including website for missing children

questions.correct_answer: C. To raise public Spending on Health to at least 2-3% of GDP
questions.explanation:
Solution:

To raise public Spending on Health to at least 2-3% of GDP The Services provided under ICPS are as follows Emergency outreach service through ‘Child line’, Dedicated number is 1098. It is a 24-hour toll-free Telephone service available to all children in distress. Open shelters for children in need, in urban and semi-urban areas. Family-based non-institutional care through Sponsorship, foster care, and Cradle baby Centres and after-care. Institutional services through shelter homes, Children’s homes, observation homes, special Homes, and specialized services for children with Special needs. Web-enabled child protection management system, Including a website for missing children. General grant-in-aid for need-based interventions.

questions.text: What is the aim of the Government scheme given in the Image below?

options.label: A
options.text: Providing conditional cash incentives to low-income families with girl children

options.label: B
options.text: Adolescent girl’s scheme under ICDS

options.label: C
options.text: Free and compulsory education for girl child

options.label: D
options.text: Scholarship scheme designed to provide financial support to young girls below poverty line

questions.correct_answer: B. Adolescent girl’s scheme under ICDS
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adolescent girl’s scheme under ICDS The given image is of KISHORI SHAKTI YOJANA (KSY): KSY is rename of ‘Adolescent Girl’s Scheme’ under ICDS (Integrated Child Development Services) Aim of KSY: To improve the nutritional and health status of adolescent girls To promote self-development, awareness of health, hygiene, nutrition, and family life and child care

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Dhanalakshmi Scheme - Providing conditional cash incentives to low-income families with girl children. Option: C. Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education (RTE) Act - Free and compulsory education for girl child Option: D. Balika Samriddhi Yojana - Scholarship scheme designed to provide financial support to young girls below the poverty line.
